results.title: The New morality
results.creator_credit: Mel Stuart, Richard Schickel and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Life goes to the movies”.
Hosted by Henry Fonda, Shirley MacLaine and Liza Minnelli. Takes a look at the life and career of Marilyn Monroe as well as the movies of the sixties. Their language, sexuality and violence portraying a new morality unthinkable a deecade earlier. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mel Stuart, Richard Schickel and Time-Life Films

results.title: The Fifties
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Life goes to the movies”.
Examines the impact of television and the courts’ decisions to separate film exhibition from production and distribution in Hollywood’s film industry during the period up to the seventies. Shows a series of film clips exemplifying the 1950’s preoccupation with romantic love themes. Suitable for Upper Secondary School Students.

results.title: The Post-war era
results.creator_credit: Mel Stuart, Richard Schickel, Malcolm Leo, Jack Haley and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Life goes to the movies”.
Hollywood turned to more mature themes in the late 1940s and early 1950s. Looks at “Film Noir” such as “Snake Pit” and “Lost Weekend”. Following McCarthyism hundreds of professionals were blacklisted. Another change of approach brought on a spate of monster films. Hosted by Henry Fonda. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The War years
results.creator_credit: Mel Stuart, Richard Schickel and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Life goes to the movies”.
Discusses Hollywood’s studio magnates and some of the 1939 spectacular films. Shows the industry’s was effort contribution via propaganda films, the creation of symbolic heroes and stars’ entertainment of the troops. Hosted by Henry Fonda and Shirley MacLaine.

results.title: Other planets: no place like Earth (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bert Shapiro, Lothar Wolff, National Educational Television and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Around Us”.
This film summarises the knowledge that scientists have gathered about the planets, covering such subjects as the seasonal changes on Mars, the atmosphere of Venus, the motion of Jupiter, the rings of Saturn, the discoveries of Neptune and Pluto. Through computer animation, viewers are taken on a “grand tour” of the outer planets (Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune) simulating a trip actually planned for an unmanned space ship in the late 1970s.

results.title: The Not so solid earth
results.creator_credit: William H Terry, Lothar Wolff and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Around Us”.
This film shows how geologists, oceanographers, paleontologists and mineralogists gather and analyse supporting data for the theory of continental drift, the dynamic system which is reshaping the earth’s surface.

results.title: A Look at sound
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Around Us”.
Very clearly, sometime using graphics, this film explains how sound works, how it is measured and what experiments have been conducted into its nature and effects. Some information about the work of Boyle and Edison is given and the physiology of the ear and nature of hearing are explained.

results.title: The Not so solid earth (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: William H Terry, Lothar Wolff and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Around Us”.
Here we trace one of the most revolutionary findings of this century: the discovery of powerful forces deep within the earth that move continents and shift oceans. Shows how geologists, oceanographers, palaeontologists and mineralogists gather and analyse supporting data for the theory of “continental drift”, the dynamic system which is reshaping the earth’s surface.
results.creator_credit_for_label: William H Terry, Lothar Wolff and Time-Life Films

results.title: The Lopsided wheel
results.creator_credit: Bedrick Rogers, L. Richard Ellison and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Around Us”.
The development of the wheel is illustrated from its invention to its use in computer machinery. Wheels of all kinds are shown and their common relation to certain laws of energy. This film highlights the problems created by wheels in the United States and other industrialised nations where there are too many, and in underdeveloped countries where there are not enough.
